title: If you see something that nobody else can see, is it still real? - Quora

response.answer_text: I can’t see things that nobody else can, but i have the dubious distinction of being able to smell and hear things others (for the most part) don’t. I was still able to ascertain those sensory perceptions were real (the smell i smelled and nobody else did turned out to be beginning rot in a bit of ground meat which the others smelled as well as soon as they opened the slightly bloated bag while the trange whirring i could trace back to a small partlet that had got loose near the ventilator of our flat) but most other people still did not hear or smelled them. And i guess the same way somebody with exceptional eye sight or eye sight better than anybody around him/her (the one eyed man being king among the blind and all that) might very well see things others don’t and still be correct. And if we are going into the realm of the supernatural… well, that’s something you got to figure out for yourself.

Many scientific breakthrpughs started-out as something that nobody else could see, but was real only to the scientist that had the initial insight. “Real” tends to withstand the test of time. Alternatively, if you can make something that “only you can see” go away by taking a pill, it’s probably not “real”. One other factor to consider is that in many situations in life there can be a huge difference between what people actually see and what they’re willing to openly admit that they see (not to mention the human propensity for seeing what they want to see). The part of the “Emperor has no clothes!” story that is rarely told (because it’s only “real” in my mind) is that the Emperor later had the boy and his family hauled-off in chains and executed (along with the others that were similarly afflicted). A good reminder to always remain aware of “real” danger.
